Fundamental Duty 7: Protect the Natural Environment

Article 51A(g) - Ecological responsibility of every citizen

🧩 Comprehensive Understanding

Article 51A(g) establishes a constitutional obligation to:

  • Conserve forests, lakes, rivers and wildlife
  • Protect natural ecosystems from degradation
  • Improve environmental quality through sustainable practices
  • Show compassion for all living creatures

This duty operationalizes the Directive Principle under Article 48A and forms the basis for India's environmental jurisprudence.

📖 Detailed Explanation

The constitutional framework for environmental protection includes:

  • Legal Framework:
    • Environment Protection Act, 1986
    • Wildlife Protection Act, 1972
    • Forest Conservation Act, 1980
    • Water and Air Pollution Control Acts
  • Policy Mechanisms:
    • National Green Tribunal
    • Pollution Control Boards
    • Compensatory Afforestation Fund
  • Citizen Responsibilities:
    • Right to clean environment under Article 21
    • Public Interest Litigation for environmental justice
    • Community participation in conservation

📜 Historical Context

This duty emerged from:

  • Global Environmental Movement:
    • 1972 Stockholm Conference
    • Growing awareness of ecological limits
  • Indian Philosophical Traditions:
    • Vedic concept of "Dharma" towards nature
    • Chipko movement's ecological consciousness
  • Constitutional Response:
    • 42nd Amendment (1976) during Emergency
    • Inspired by Gandhian principles of sustainable living
    • Complemented by DPSP Article 48A

🏛️ Judicial Interpretations

  • Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum v. Union of India (1996) : Established "Precautionary Principle" and "Polluter Pays" doctrine. [(1996) 5 SCC 647]
  • M.C. Mehta v. Union of India (1987) : Pioneered environmental PILs and introduced CNG for public transport. [AIR 1987 SC 1086]
  • T.N. Godavarman Thirumulpad v. Union of India (1997) : Expanded forest protection through continuing mandamus. [(1997) 2 SCC 267]

🔍 Contemporary Challenges

  • Climate change adaptation and mitigation
  • Balancing development with conservation
  • Plastic pollution and waste management
  • Air quality crisis in urban areas
  • Implementation of Paris Agreement commitments
); }
